The death of a father. Our inescapable mortality. The realization that even the darkest times in life can be followed by hope. Manchester OrchestraÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s debut album IÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢m Like a Virgin Losing a Child does not stray from weighted issues on singer/guitarist/songwriter Andy HullÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s chest. This album was first released in late 2006, but was re-released on July of 2007, which is when I received a copy and heard the band for the first time. I requested IÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢m Like a Virgin Losing a Child, because I recalled Jared Kaufman having an affinity for the band, and I trusted his judgment. ItÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s been months since first spinning this album, and as IÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ve moved my attention (ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œaffectionÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ may be a better word) from first song to last, IÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢m in with Manchester Orchestra for the long haul.

In searching for a way to describe IÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢m Like a Virgin Losing a Child, I keep coming back to the word ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œheavy.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ I do not mean heavy in the gravitational sense (I wouldnÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t want to confuse Doc Brown), but as a fullness thatÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s anything but shallow. In writing songs Hull crafts characters and connects them to emotions - not the kind of theatrical fluff littering mainstream Hollywood, but the sort found in a beloved and dog-eared paperback of short stories. The album is craftily introduced by one of the more upbeat and quickly accessible songs in Manchester OrchestraÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s collection, ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œWolves at Night.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ Keyboardist Chris Freeman sets a pop/synth rock tone for the band initially, and it is an enjoyable sound, but itÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s soon discovered that both highs and lows encompass Manchester OrchestraÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s full sound. ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œI Can Feel Your PainÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ slows the pace down and finds Hull alone with a guitar, continuing the theme of Christianity found throughout the album: ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œI compared your Jesus to a thief / And he took my bones and he turned them into bread.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½

There is beauty found in these songs for anyone seeking it. I was taken in by ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œWolves at NightÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ and ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œNow That You're Home,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ the first two songs found on the album, but it was ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œSleeper 1972ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ that brought everything to a standstill. A minimalist approach to instrumentation places emphasis on what matters most in the sorrow filled narration; that is, HullÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s hushed voice and storytelling ability. There is not a word wasted in his introduction:

When my dad died
The worms ate out both his eyes
His soul flew right up in the sky
I cried myself to sleep

Hull hangs the black cloud of a funeral home over a familyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s home that should be filled with joy, one in which a mother longs for her own death and a sister finds herself alone as emotions are turned inward and only serve to suffocate. This is the heaviness I was referring to earlier. Perhaps the best aspect of IÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢m Like a Virgin Losing a Child is its ability to include varying emotions as part of separate scenes, so each song is of its own importance, but when placed alongside each other they feel stronger in their togetherness. The most recent Manchester Orchestra song to be placed on repeat on my music players has been ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œAlice and Interiors,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ the title of which shows the bandÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s fondness for filmmaker Woody Allen. A desperate message to a fleeting love, Hull finds himself shouting out for one last chance and questions his own visibility, since his phone calls remain unanswered despite his attempts. After an interlude to contemplate his codependence and the futility of his efforts, Hull changes his tune, turning his frustrations outward to the one who wonÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t listen. ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‹Å“Cause the truth is that no one truly knows

Months ago Manchester Orchestra were picking up steam; they were often talked about, and people were excited about the prospect of a new and talented young band. Maybe those people expected immediate gratification in the form of a new album, and by this point theyÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ve moved their interests elsewhere. I hope for their sake thatÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s not the case, because this album and this band deserve the attention of a wide and appreciative audience. I would like new music from Manchester Orchestra, but thereÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s no need to rush the band - I'm Like a Virgin Losing a Child could hold me over for years.
